GeneralExplanationGrp.MediumExplanationTxt: Effective October 1, 2007, the Foundation established a Group Long Term Care Insurance Plan covering employees with ten years of service, consultants with ten years of service as an employee and their spouses and domestic partners. The plan provides, among other things, that after premiums have been paid for ten years for an employee and the employee spouse or domestic partner, their coverage will be automatically renewed for the rest of their lives without any further premium payments.

Effective October 1, 2007, the Foundation established two related, unfunded deferred compensation plans which together provide an annual benefit in excess of the maximum contribution allowed by the Internal Revenue Code for the year under the Foundation's Tax Sheltered Retirement Plan.

For the grants to individuals paid during the year and the grants approved for future payment to individuals, none of the individuals have any relationship to any foundation manager or substantial contributor.

Statements Regarding Activities for Which Form 4720 May Be Required Open Society Institute ("OSI") made a matching gift of $450 to Christian Ministries International, Inc. Subsequent to payment of this grants, it was determined that grantee was a private operating foundation described in section 4942(j)(3) rather than an exempt operating foundation described in 4940(d)(2). OSI did not exercise expenditure responsibility on this one grant representing approximately .002% of all grants paid in 2018. Accordingly, question Part VII-B, 5(b) is answered yes and question Part VII- 5(c) no. This matching gift is not treated as a qualifying distribution and Open Society Institute is in the process of recovering the matching gift from Christian Ministries International Inc.
